{bc}to be a specified height when fully erect
{bc}to take up or maintain a specified position or posture
{bc}to be in a particular state or situation
{bc}to have or maintain a relative position in or as if in a graded scale
{bc}to be in a position to gain or lose because of an action taken or a commitment made
{bc}to rest or remain upright on a base or lower end

dt.t: the car {it}stood{/it} in the garage for a week

dt: used chiefly in the expression {it}it stands to reason{/it}
{bc}to exist in a definite written or printed form

dt.t: copy a passage exactly as it {wi}stands{/wi}
the order given last week still {wi}stands{/wi}
this book will {wi}stand{/wi} the test of time

dt: {bc}to endure the presence or personality of

dt: {bc}to remain firm in the face of
{bc}to pay the cost of (a treat) {bc}pay for
{bc}to exhibit courage, strength, or calm especially in the face of adversity
{bc}to pay the cost of food, drink, or entertainment for others in a group

pt: {sc}bear{/sc} {sc}suffer{/sc} {sc}endure{/sc} {sc}abide{/sc} {sc}tolerate{/sc} {sc}stand{/sc} mean to put up with something trying or painful. {sc}bear{/sc} usually implies the power to sustain without flinching or breaking.
{sc}suffer{/sc} often suggests acceptance or passivity rather than courage or patience in bearing.
{sc}endure{/sc} implies continuing firm or resolute through trials and difficulties.
{sc}abide{/sc} suggests acceptance without resistance or protest.
{sc}tolerate{/sc} suggests overcoming or successfully controlling an impulse to resist, avoid, or resent something injurious or distasteful.
{sc}stand{/sc} emphasizes even more strongly the ability to bear without discomposure or flinching.

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}standan{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}stantan, stān{/it} to stand, Latin {it}stare{/it}, Greek {it}histanai{/it} to cause to stand, set, {it}histasthai{/it} to stand, be standing
shortdef: to support oneself on the feet in an erect position
to be a specified height when fully erect
to rise to an erect position

dt.t: For example, Kafka is presented as a profoundly unhappy, deliberately {wi}self-condemned{/wi} fellow who often thought of himself with the pseudonym of {ldquo}the Bachelor{rdquo} …
The lazy person has to look on hard workers as fools; otherwise he {phrase}stands self-condemned{/phrase} …

shortdef: condemned by oneself
